hello i ve not posted here before but i ve wanted to for a while always debating back and forth whether or not to do this but here it go i think i have some general anxiety i cope decently well with it physical exercise like running ha really helped my main problem is driving i know how to drive i have my license but i never do i m terrified of it i m turning i ve maybe driven thirty time in my entire 0 year of owning a license i don t know what it is the idea of crashing the traffic i ve gotten away with it so far living in nyc but it s something i want to do more of i just never seem to be able to do so doe anyone have any tip any advice they could recommend thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out and shared your experience with anxiety. I can understand how challenging it must be for you to deal with the fear of driving, especially since you've been able to cope well with physical exercise like running.

To address your fear of driving, it might be helpful to start small and gradually build up your confidence. You could consider taking short drives around your neighborhood or even in an empty parking lot to get used to being behind the wheel. This way, you can become more familiar with the process without feeling overwhelmed by traffic or other drivers.

Another suggestion is to try different relaxation techniques before getting behind the wheel. Deep breathing exercises or listening to calming music can help reduce anxiety and make you feel more at ease. Additionally, it may be beneficial to visualize yourself successfully driving and feeling confident on the road.

It could also be helpful to create a plan for your first few driving experiences. You might want to consider taking a friend or family member along for support. Having someone with you can provide reassurance and help alleviate some of the anxiety.

Lastly, remember that progress takes time and patience. It's important to be kind to yourself and not get discouraged if you have setbacks or feel anxious at times. Celebrate even the smallest victories and remind yourself that it's okay to take things one step at a time.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and it's great that you're taking steps to address your fear of driving.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have suffered with shortness of breath due to anxiety ever since i wa diagnosed with gad generalized anxiety disorder about year ago doe anyone else have this it just feel like i will stop breathing doe anyone have any coping mechanism around this a it s really horrible a well a shortness of breath i also feel shaky and tingly and i have no idea how to calm down when i have these episode

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging to experience shortness of breath due to anxiety, especially when it has been a persistent issue for you since being diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this, as many individuals with anxiety also experience similar symptoms.

One coping mechanism that may help is deep breathing exercises. When you feel the onset of shortness of breath or anxiety, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focus on fully exhaling and allow your body to relax as you do so. Deep breathing can help regulate your breathing and bring a sense of calm.

Another technique that might be helpful is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. By consciously tensing and relaxing each muscle group, you can help release tension and promote relaxation.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety and shortness of breath. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters, and can help reduce feelings of anxiety. Find an activity that you enjoy and try to incorporate it into your routine.

In addition to these techniques, it can be helpful to identify any triggers or patterns that may contribute to your episodes of shortness of breath and anxiety. Keeping a journal can be a useful tool for tracking your thoughts, feelings, and experiences during these episodes. This can help you identify any common themes or triggers that you can then work on managing or avoiding.

Lastly, seeking support from loved ones or joining a support group for individuals with anxiety can provide you with a sense of community and understanding. Sharing your experiences with others who have similar struggles can be comforting and validating.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. It's important to be patient with yourself and give yourself time to explore different coping mechanisms. If you find that your symptoms persist or worsen, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time at work, and I can understand how frustrating and overwhelming it must be for you. It's completely normal to feel anxious and stressed about your performance, especially in a new job.

First of all, I want to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out and share your concerns. It takes a lot of strength to put yourself out there like this. I'm here to support you and offer some guidance on how to navigate this challenging situation.

One thing that might be helpful is to try and focus on the things you can control, such as your attitude and effort. While it may be difficult, try to remind yourself that you are doing your best and that everyone makes mistakes. It's important to remember that making mistakes doesn't define who you are as a person.

In terms of managing your anxiety and stress, it might be beneficial to explore different coping mechanisms. This could include finding healthy ways to relax and unwind outside of work, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time with loved ones. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you recharge can make a big difference in how you feel overall.

Additionally, it might be helpful to create a daily routine that includes time for self-care. This could include setting aside time each day to take care of yourself physically and mentally. This could involve things like getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that help you relax and recharge.

Regarding your job security, it's important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people experience periods of uncertainty in their careers. While it's natural to worry about the future, try not to let these thoughts consume you. Instead, focus on what you can control in the present moment.

When it comes to your relationship with your parents and girlfriend, it's important to remember that they care about you and want to support you. It's okay to vent to them, but try not to burden them with your worries all the time. It might be helpful to find other outlets for your emotions, such as journaling or talking to a trusted friend.

Lastly, I'm glad to hear that you've started seeing a therapist recently. Therapy can be a valuable resource in helping you navigate these challenges. Your therapist can provide you with additional tools and strategies to manage your anxiety and stress, as well as offer support and guidance throughout this process.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself. Change takes time, and it's okay to have setbacks along the way. Keep focusing on your strengths and the progress you've made so far. And don't hesitate to reach out to your support system when you need it.

I hope this guidance helps you in managing your anxiety and stress, and I'm here to support you throughout this process.

[Question]
i ve noticed that for a few glorious minute in the morning right after waking up i m great calm unbothered soft but then i can feel stress in my body and then i m not sure how to get rid of it and it build a anxiety doe how do you all get rid of body stress in the early morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've noticed those few minutes of calmness in the morning! It can be really helpful to try and hold onto that feeling as long as possible. Here are some suggestions that might help you get rid of body stress and anxiety in the early morning:

1. Start your day with a positive mindset: When you wake up, try to think about something positive or something you're looking forward to. This can help set a positive tone for your day.

2. Practice deep breathing exercises: Deep breathing can help relax your body and mind. Take a few moments to focus on your breath and inhale deeply through your nose, holding it for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this a few times to help calm your body.

3. Stretch and move your body: Sometimes, stress and anxiety can build up in our bodies. Taking a few minutes to stretch and move around can help release some of that tension. You can try gentle yoga poses or even just stretching your arms and legs.

4. Engage in a morning ritual: Having a morning ritual can help signal to your body that it's time to wake up and start the day. It could be something as simple as making your bed, having a cup of tea or coffee, or listening to calming music. Find something that works for you and make it a part of your routine.

5. Practice mindfulness or meditation: Taking a few moments each morning to be present and aware of your thoughts and feelings can help reduce stress and anxiety. You can try meditation or mindfulness exercises to help ground yourself and bring your focus back to the present moment.

6. Prioritize self-care: Make sure you're taking care of yourself throughout the day and night. Get enough sleep, eat well, and engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Taking care of your physical and emotional well-being can help reduce stress and anxiety.

7. Reach out for support: If you're feeling overwhelmed by stress and anxiety, it can be helpful to talk to someone about it. Reach out to a trusted friend or family member, or consider seeking support from a mental health professional. Sometimes, just talking about your feelings can help alleviate some of the stress.

Remember, everyone's experience with stress and anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and give these suggestions a try. If you continue to struggle with body stress and anxiety in the early morning, it might be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i 9 f moved to a different state to support my partner while they re at school we went from a duel income household to me being the breadwinner i wa diagnosed with adhd anxiety and depression last year and am on med and in therapy i just keep screwing up at work the work isn t hard but i m making stupid mistake i feel like im not doing anything correctly i try to be thorough and am told by my bos that i m getting too caught up in the detail i try to be quick and cover the basic and am told that it isn t my best work i have no idea what to do i m told to ask question if i don t understand by my bos and when i do she s short with me example i asked if i should include document with a proposal because the last time i did there wa push back from someone saying they didn t need to provide the document she replied if i wa asking if i needed to follow to the standard operative procedure i feel stuck my performance ha been worse partially due to depression which ha affected my focus cue adhd issue med for that aren t working great i just feel so stuck i m literally cry once a week bc i feel like i m failing so badly i m literally doing working extra because i m behind and not charging for it bc i just feel like i m so behind i started this new job and wa immediately sent home to telework full time so i can t just ask the people around me for help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to acknowledge the strength it takes to reach out for support. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to help improve your situation.

Firstly, it's great that you're in therapy and on medication for your ADHD, anxiety, and depression. These tools can be incredibly helpful in managing your symptoms and improving your overall well-being. It might be worth discussing with your therapist how they can help you navigate the challenges you're facing at work. They can provide guidance on strategies to manage your ADHD symptoms, such as time management techniques or organizational tools, which may help you feel more in control of your workload. Additionally, they can help you explore coping mechanisms for dealing with the stress and anxiety that come with making mistakes at work.

Regarding your work situation, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes from time to time, and it's not a reflection of your worth as a person. However, it might be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your boss about your concerns. You could explain that you're feeling overwhelmed and ask if there are any resources or support systems available to help you. They may be able to offer guidance on how to approach your work more effectively or suggest strategies for managing your time and tasks more efficiently.

In terms of your feelings of failure and being stuck, it's crucial to practice self-compassion. Remember that nobody is perfect, and it's okay to make mistakes. Instead of focusing on what you've done wrong, try to focus on what you can do to improve moving forward. Break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps and celebrate each small success along the way.

Lastly, regarding your performance at work, it might be helpful to explore alternative solutions for your ADHD medication. You mentioned that it isn't working as well as you'd like, so discussing this with your doctor could be a good first step. They may be able to suggest alternative medications or adjust your current dosage to see if that helps improve your focus and concentration.

Remember, it's important to take care of yourself during this time. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Building a strong support network can also be incredibly helpful, whether that's through friends, family, or online communities.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you, and I encourage you to reach out to your therapist or healthcare provider for additional support and guidance. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it, and there are people who care about you and want to see you succeed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve had this ever since i wa young and now that i m in my adult year i feel like i m running out of time i m still at home and i feel stuck i can t hold down a job i ve lost over job let alone my therapist keep telling me to be compassionate towards myself but it s so hard i just want to be normal be happy my panic attack are bothering me lately more than ever and idk how to help it

 I can see that you've been dealing with anxiety and panic attacks for a long time, and it's understandable that you feel frustrated and stuck. It's important to remember that everyone's journey with mental health is unique, and it takes time and effort to find what works best for you.

Your history of struggling with anxiety and panic attacks is not uncommon, and it's essential to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out for help. I'd like to explore some strategies that may help you manage your anxiety and panic attacks more effectively.

First, let's discuss some relaxation techniques that can help you during a panic attack. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization are all effective methods. You might also find it helpful to practice mindfulness meditation or yoga. These techniques can help you focus on the present moment and reduce feelings of anxiety.

Second, let's consider cognitive-behavioral strategies. This approach involves identifying and challenging negative thoughts and replacing them with more positive and realistic ones. For example, instead of thinking "I'll never be normal," you might reframe it as "I'm doing the best I can with the resources I have." This can help shift your perspective and reduce feelings of anxiety.

Lastly, let's explore the possibility of working with a psychologist or therapist to develop a more comprehensive treatment plan. They can provide you with additional tools and resources to help manage your anxiety and panic attacks. Additionally, they can help you explore any underlying emotional or psychological issues that may be contributing to your anxiety.

Remember, it's essential to be patient with yourself and recognize that progress may not always be linear. It's also crucial to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. I'm here to support you in any way I can, and together we can work towards finding effective strategies to help you manage your anxiety and panic attacks.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time with your spouse and the upcoming arrival of your baby. It sounds like he has been dealing with severe depression for a long time, and it's understandable that you're worried about how this new addition to your family will impact him.

Regarding your concerns about the mental hospital, it's important to remember that every individual's experience with mental health treatment is unique. While I can't predict whether or not the hospital will be able to help him, I can offer some suggestions that might help improve his situation.

Firstly, it's crucial to continue supporting him in seeking help. Encourage him to open up about his feelings and let him know that you're there for him. It's essential to create a safe and non-judgmental space for him to express himself.

Secondly, consider reaching out to his counselor or therapist to discuss his concerns. They may be able to provide additional guidance or support to help him feel more comfortable with the idea of going to the hospital.

Thirdly, it might be helpful to explore alternative treatment options that could potentially benefit him. For example, you could look into online resources or support groups that offer guidance and coping strategies for individuals dealing with depression.

Fourthly, try to maintain a routine and structure in his life as much as possible. This can provide a sense of stability and help him feel more grounded. Encourage him to engage in activities that bring him joy or a sense of accomplishment, even if they're small.

Lastly, remember to take care of yourself as well. Dealing with a loved one's mental health struggles can be incredibly challenging, and it's essential to prioritize your own well-being. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

I hope these suggestions can help you navigate this difficult situation. Remember, it's important to be patient and understanding with your spouse, as healing takes time. If you have any other concerns or questions, please feel free to share them. I'm here to support you both as best I can.

i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of challenges when it comes to managing your anxiety and depression. I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions that may help you find relief.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's experience with mental health is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's great that you've tried various methods like meditation, exercise, and therapy, but it seems like none of them have had a significant impact on your symptoms.

Given your description of feeling constantly on edge and having physical symptoms like a pounding heart, it might be helpful to consider reaching out to a healthcare professional who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide you with a proper diagnosis and explore other treatment options that may be more effective for you.

In the meantime, there are a few things you can try to help manage your anxiety. One approach is deep breathing exercises, which can help calm your body and mind. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this process several times whenever you feel anxious.

Another technique you can try is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups in your body to promote relaxation. You can find guided videos or audio recordings online that can help you with this technique.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore mindfulness practices such as meditation or yoga. These activities can help you focus on the present moment and reduce stress and anxiety. There are many resources available online or through mobile apps that can guide you through these practices.

Lastly, I want to acknowledge the frustration and difficulty you've been experiencing. It's important to remember that managing anxiety and depression takes time and patience. It's not uncommon to try various methods before finding something that works for you. Keep an open mind and be willing to try new things. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being.

I hope these suggestions can help you find some relief from your symptoms. Remember, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

so i started having suicidal thought in april of last year and they lasted until around november in october i started hanging out with a girl and we started becoming good friend not romantic just friendship my mental health started getting a lot better after a couple month of friendship with her and it s kept getting better ever since a few day ago i made a passive aggressive comment that really upset her she won t text me back now i ve tried apologizing and trying to make thing right with her but i haven t heard back from her i m afraid i ve ruined this friendship forever and now my suicidal thought are back for the first time since last year i always hurt the people that i care about and i hate myself so much that i do this

 It sounds like you've been through a lot, and I'm here to support you. It's understandable that you're feeling worried and concerned about your mental health and the impact it has had on your relationships.

Regarding your friendship with the girl, it's unfortunate that things haven't worked out as you had hoped. It's important to remember that relationships can have ups and downs, and sometimes conflicts arise. While it's natural to feel disappointed and worried about the situation, it's essential to give yourself time to process your emotions and communicate openly with your friend. It might be helpful to consider writing her a letter or reaching out to her through other means if you haven't already done so.

It's also crucial to address the self-blame and feelings of hating yourself. Remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's a natural part of being human. It's essential to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that you deserve love and understanding, just like anyone else.

In terms of your mental health, it's important to continue attending your therapy sessions and maintaining open communication with your therapist. They can provide you with strategies and tools to help manage your thoughts and emotions. Additionally, consider exploring other coping mechanisms such as exercise, mindfulness, or engaging in activities that bring you joy.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Reach out to friends, family, or even helplines if you're feeling overwhelmed. You don't have to face this alone, and there are people who care about you and want to support you.

Take care of yourself, and remember that it's okay to ask for help.

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been struggling with your stutter for a long time, and it's great that you've had an epiphany about how you've been letting it control you. It's important to remember that you are not defined by your stutter, but rather by the person you choose to be.

I understand that it can be challenging to see yourself as confident and charismatic when you're feeling anxious and weird about your stutter. However, it's crucial to remember that how you perceive yourself is how others will perceive you as well. If you see yourself as confident and charismatic, then others will see you that way too.

One approach that might help you is to practice self-compassion. Be kind to yourself and remind yourself that everyone makes mistakes and has challenges. Instead of focusing on the stutter, try to focus on the things that make you unique and special. Celebrate your strengths and achievements, and remind yourself that your stutter doesn't define who you are as a person.

Another helpful strategy is to challenge negative thoughts and replace them with positive ones. When you catch yourself thinking negatively about your stutter, try to reframe those thoughts into more positive and empowering ones. For example, instead of thinking "I'm weird," try to think "I'm unique and interesting."

It might also be helpful to practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help manage your anxiety. These techniques can help you feel more calm and confident when speaking.

Additionally, consider seeking support from others who have similar experiences. There are online communities and support groups where you can connect with people who understand what it's like to live with a stutter. Sharing your experiences and hearing from others can be incredibly empowering and help you feel less alone.

Lastly, remember that progress takes time and effort. It won't happen overnight, but with consistent practice and self-compassion, you can gradually build confidence and overcome the anxiety that fuels your stutter.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you. Remember, you have the power to choose how you perceive yourself and how you present yourself to others. You are not defined by your stutter, but rather by the person you choose to be.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m terrible at articulating my thought so apology in advance let me just say up front that no plan ha been made and despite thinking about it so much i don t think i could go through with it this is just a vent piece i guess i feel like such a burden all the time i genuinely only have one real friend left and feel like my roommate co worker hate me i m anti social and awkward i don t make eye contact and i don t talk at all ever i take way too long to text back if i did km i honestly don t think anyone would know until a body wa found or over a month had passed i m just so sick of feeling like an obstacle all the time like i m always in the way or always wrong to think feel a certain way but all of this seems pretty normal i realise it s not a healthy mindset but literally everyone on earth ha trauma everyone ha their own shit they re going through and not only doe it seem like they re handling it a lot better than me but they have real problem i have friend who lost their job over the pandemic i have friend going through break ups grief or whatever and they still manage to practice their hobby and interact with their fellow man but then there s me doing literally fucking nothing all day every day after work and having the ball to feel like shit over it a if it s out of my control i feel weak willed lazy and most of all i feel like the world s biggist egomaniac for writing so much about myself a if it needed to be said thank you for reading my aimless rambling the thought were very intrusive tonight so i just needed to self depricate i guess good night everyone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand how difficult it is for you to express your thoughts and feelings, and I appreciate your honesty. It takes a lot of courage to share such personal details about yourself. I'm here to listen and support you, so please don't apologize for the length of your message.

It's important to remember that these feelings are subjective and may not accurately reflect the reality of your relationships. This could involve setting achievable goals, such as practicing mindfulness or engaging in activities that bring you joy.

It's essential to remember that everyone has their own struggles and challenges, and it's not a competition. Comparing ourselves to others can often lead to feelings of inadequacy and self-criticism. Instead, try to focus on your own progress and growth.

Many people struggle with feelings of being in the way or always being wrong. However, it's crucial to challenge these thoughts and remind yourself that you're deserving of love, respect, and compassion.

You also mentioned feeling like you're doing nothing all day every day after work. It's essential to find ways to fill your time with activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. This could involve pursuing hobbies, engaging in creative outlets, or even volunteering.

Lastly, I want to acknowledge the courage it took for you to share your thoughts and feelings with me. It's not easy to put ourselves out there, especially when we're feeling vulnerable. I'm here to support you and help you navigate these challenging emotions.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. You don't have to face these challenges alone. I'm here to listen, support, and guide you through this process. Together, we can work towards finding ways to improve your mental well-being and help you feel more at ease with yourself.

[Question]
hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It seems like you're experiencing a significant drop in performance this year compared to last year in your mathletics competitions. It's understandable that seeing the leaderboard and feeling anxious about your ranking can be stressful and affect your overall performance.

To help calm yourself down and regain some confidence, here are a few suggestions:

1. Focus on the process: Instead of solely focusing on the leaderboard and comparing yourself to others, try to shift your attention to the process of learning and improving. Remember that it's not just about winning or being at the top, but also about growing and developing your skills.

2. Set realistic goals: Instead of aiming for the top spot, set smaller, achievable goals for yourself. This can help alleviate some of the pressure and allow you to enjoy the competition without feeling overwhelmed by expectations.

3. Practice self-care: Taking care of your mental and physical well-being is crucial in managing stress. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: When you start feeling stressed or anxious about the competition, try to challenge any negative thoughts that may be contributing to your feelings. Remind yourself that everyone has ups and downs, and it's okay to have a setback now and then.

5. Seek support: If you find that your mixed feelings and stress are interfering with your enjoyment of the competition, consider reaching out to a trusted friend, family member, or teacher for support. Sometimes talking about your concerns can help provide a fresh perspective and offer guidance.

6. Practice relaxation techniques: Learning relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help calm your mind and body during stressful situations. These techniques can be practiced regularly to help manage anxiety and promote overall well-being.

7. Take breaks: It's important to give yourself time to rest and recharge. Taking breaks during competitions can help prevent burnout and allow you to come back with renewed energy and focus.

Remember, everyone has their ups and downs, and it's normal to experience setbacks. Try to be kind to yourself and focus on the process rather than the outcome. If these feelings persist or become overwhelming, it may be helpful to seek additional support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and strategies for managing stress and anxiety.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a range of symptoms that have been concerning you for quite some time. It's important to acknowledge the impact these symptoms have had on your life and to seek support in understanding and addressing them.

Firstly, I want to reassure you that it's not uncommon for people to experience memory loss as they age. It's also possible that your weight loss, lack of motivation, and passive intrusive thoughts could be related to other factors such as stress, anxiety, or depression. These conditions can often manifest in various ways, including changes in appetite, sleep patterns, and sexual function.

Given the complexity of your situation, it might be helpful to consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with a more comprehensive evaluation and support. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your symptoms and develop strategies to manage them effectively.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to help improve your overall well-being. Regular exercise, even if it's just a short walk, can have positive effects on mood and energy levels. Additionally, maintaining a balanced diet and ensuring you get enough sleep can contribute to better mental health.

i feel like wanting to die why do i not have friend i feel soo empty lonely i mean i do have a lot of people i talk to on a daily basis but for some reason i feel the need to always have someone almost all the time with me like if i stay alone for hour i feel lonely it is weird i just wish to be happy i don t want to kill myself

You mentioned having a lot of people you talk to on a daily basis, but it's worth considering reaching out to friends or family members who you feel comfortable with and trust. Additionally, joining groups or clubs that align with your interests can be a great way to meet new people and find like-minded individuals. This can help you expand your social circle and potentially form deeper connections.

It's also important to take care of yourself physically. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and make you feel good about yourself can boost your mood and overall well-being. This could include things like exercise, hobbies, or even just taking time for yourself to relax and recharge.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. [Question]
i live at home and i love my parent but i m beginning to spiral after an incident month ago i ve been profoundly depressed and stressed out i wa renting but moved back home to save money while trying to get myself back in order especially because my med stopped working i m an only child and my parent have no friend so now that i m back home all they want to do is constantly talk to me i already have poor sleep a it is but it could be am and my dad will shake me awake to talk about a car or his work day or my mom will come in and talk to me about my finance or why i never talk to her about my mental health one time recently i had been woken up so abruptly i could feel my entire nervous system jolt like i had been struck by lighting even thinking about it make my entire body randomly hurt i never get to be alone anymore i try to get alone time but i never get it for more than a couple hour at an time bc of the sleep deprivation i hallucinate now i hear and see thing i honestly wish somthing would happen to me and it would just all end life s so stressful and the little thing aren t fun anymore i hate myself i hate everything i used to love nothing fun anymore what s the fucking point

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand how difficult it is for you to feel trapped in this situation and struggling with your mental health. It's important to remember that you're not alone, and there are steps you can take to regain control over your life.

Firstly, it might be helpful to establish some boundaries with your parents. Communicate openly and honestly about how their constant talking is affecting you. Let them know that you need some alone time to focus on your mental health. You could also consider setting specific times during the day when you'll engage in conversation with them, and then respectfully ask for some quiet time during other hours.

In terms of your sleep, it's crucial to prioritize it. Try to establish a consistent bedtime routine and create a calm environment in your bedroom. Avoid stimulating activities or screens before bed, and consider using relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation to help you unwind. If possible, discuss your sleep concerns with your parents and ask if they can be more considerate of your needs.

Regarding your hallucinations, it's essential to seek professional help. A mental health professional can provide you with the necessary support and guidance to manage these symptoms effectively. They can also help you explore any underlying causes for your depression and stress.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to improve your mood and overall well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation, such as hobbies or exercise, can help alleviate some of the stress and sadness you're experiencing. Additionally, practicing mindfulness and gratitude can help shift your focus away from negative thoughts and bring more positivity into your life.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and support when you need it. Reach out to friends, family, or a mental health professional who can offer guidance and understanding. You deserve to live a life that feels fulfilling and enjoyable, and with the right support and strategies, you can work towards achieving that.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve so many health issue and i m only starting with atopic and seborrhoeic dermatitis and psoriasis through endometriosis and hypothyroidism to ibs fucked up hip and pelvic floor and that s not even all and obviously only phisical thing that are wrong and i really try to take care of all of this problem but it s exhausting and for what to live in a world where everything is getting more and more fucked up every minute the pandemic the war the famine that s probably gon na come soon a a result of the war i m polish so very much can feel the effect of what s happening in ukraine i m also vegan and knowing that so many animal are still suffering and the price of everything are going up i don t even think i can afford to live anymore and i m really trying going on a walk in the forest everyday doing yoga eating healthy just generally taking care of myself like a normal person would but i just can t see the light at the end of the tunnel rant over

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I hear you, and I want to acknowledge the many challenges you're facing. It's not easy to deal with a multitude of health issues, especially when they're all interconnected and affect different aspects of your life. It's understandable that you feel exhausted and overwhelmed.

First, let's focus on your physical health. It's great that you're taking care of yourself by eating healthy, going for walks in the forest, and practicing yoga. These are all positive steps towards managing your health conditions. I encourage you to continue with these practices and explore other self-care activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

Now, let's address the emotional and mental well-being. It's natural to feel frustrated and helpless when faced with so many challenges. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people around the world are experiencing similar emotions due to the ongoing pandemic, war, famine, and other global issues.

In times like these, it can be helpful to focus on what we can control in our lives. While we may not be able to change the world, we can still make a difference in our own lives. Consider setting small, achievable goals for yourself each day. This could be as simple as taking a short walk, practicing mindfulness, or engaging in a hobby that brings you joy.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to seek support from others. Connecting with friends, family, or support groups can provide a sense of belonging and understanding. Sharing your experiences and feelings with others who may be going through similar challenges can be a powerful source of comfort and validation.

Lastly, remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. If you're feeling overwhelmed or struggling to cope, don't hesitate to reach out to a mental health professional. They can provide guidance, support, and help you develop strategies to manage your emotions and find ways to thrive despite the challenges.

I hope this message finds you well, and I'm here to support you in any way I can. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take things one step at a time. You're not alone, and there are resources available to help you navigate these challenging times.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

In the meantime, there are some things you can do to help manage your anxiety and improve your sleep. Establishing a consistent sleep routine can be helpful, as it signals to your body when it's time to sleep and wake up. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time each day, even on weekends. Creating a relaxing bedtime routine can also help signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep. This could include activities like reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation.

Engaging in regular physical activity during the day can also help improve your sleep quality. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters and can help reduce anxiety and stress. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate exercise most days of the week.

Additionally, it may be helpful to explore some coping strategies for managing stress and anxiety. This could include practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation, or seeking support from friends, family, or a support group.

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you've been going through such a difficult time. It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of loss and stress, and it's understandable that it's been affecting your emotional well-being. I want you to know that you're not alone, and there are some things you can try to help yourself feel more grounded and centered.

First, it might be helpful to focus on your breathing. Taking slow, deep breaths can help calm your body and mind. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Another technique you can try is grounding yourself in the present moment. This involves using your senses to connect with your surroundings. You can do this by focusing on what you can see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. For example, you could look around and name five things you can see, four things you can hear, three things you can smell, two things you can taste, and one thing you can touch. This can help bring your attention back to the present moment and away from any anxious thoughts or worries.

It might also be helpful to engage in activities that bring you joy or help you relax. This could be something as simple as listening to music, reading a book, or taking a warm bath. Engaging in activities that you enjoy can help distract your mind from negative thoughts and provide a sense of comfort and relaxation.

Lastly, it's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it. If you're feeling overwhelmed or struggling to cope, it can be helpful to reach out to a trusted friend or family member. They may be able to offer support and guidance, or even come and visit you if you're feeling isolated. If you're comfortable doing so, you could also consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional support and guidance tailored to your specific needs.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you, and I'm here to support you in any way I can. Remember, it's okay to ask for help, and you don't have to face this alone.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i fell pain on my left chest and on my left back when i looking for an answer on google i feel it s a symptom of heart disease my mother also ha this and a far a i know heart disease can be inherited i didn t dare to go to the doctor because in our family there is a saying that say it s better not to know

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing some concerning symptoms, and it's important to take them seriously. While I'm not a medical professional, I can offer some guidance and suggestions.

Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize your health and well-being. Although it may be challenging, it's essential to seek medical attention when you have concerns about your health. Ignoring symptoms could potentially lead to further complications or delays in receiving proper treatment.

Secondly, regarding your mother's health, it's essential to keep an eye on her condition as well. While heart disease can be inherited, it doesn't mean that you will definitely develop it. However, it's still important to monitor any changes in your health and discuss them with a healthcare provider.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to help alleviate your symptoms. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help reduce stress and anxiety. Additionally, maintaining a healthy lifestyle by eating nutritious meals, getting regular exercise, and avoiding excessive alcohol or tobacco use can also contribute to overall well-being.

Lastly, it's essential to challenge the idea that "it's better not to know" when it comes to your health. Ignoring symptoms or not seeking medical attention can lead to unnecessary suffering and potential complications. Remember, you deserve to prioritize your health and well-being, and seeking medical attention is a sign of strength, not weakness.

I hope these suggestions help you navigate this situation. Remember, I'm here to support you, and if you ever need someone to talk to, I'm always here to listen.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 I'm here to listen and support you through this difficult time. It sounds like you're going through a lot of emotions right now, and it's understandable that you're feeling hurt and disappointed. It's important to remember that relationships can be complex, and sometimes they don't work out the way we hope.

One thing to consider is that it's not uncommon for people to have feelings for their friends, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions when those feelings aren't reciprocated. It's important to give yourself time to process these emotions and allow yourself to grieve the loss of the friendship.

It might be helpful to reach out to other friends or family members who can provide support and understanding during this time. You mentioned that you're an introvert, but even introverts need social support and connection. Consider reaching out to people you trust and feel comfortable with, and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes just talking about our feelings with someone who cares can help us make sense of things.

Additionally, it might be helpful to engage in activities that bring you joy and help you feel connected to yourself. This could include hobbies, exercise, or creative pursuits. Engaging in activities that make you feel good can help improve your mood and overall well-being.

It's also important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way. Relationships can be challenging, and it's normal to experience heartbreak and disappointment. It might be helpful to remind yourself that these feelings are temporary and that you'll find love and happiness again in the future.

Lastly, if you're feeling suicidal or having thoughts of self-harm, please reach out to a mental health professional or emergency services immediately. They can provide you with the support and resources you need to stay safe. Remember, there are people who care about you and want to help.

 I'm here to listen and support you, and I appreciate you reaching out. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now. It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and depressed about your current situation. Comparing yourself to others can be a common experience, but it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique. You've been through a lot of trauma and it's natural to feel self-hatred and disappointment. However, it's crucial to remember that you deserve love, compassion, and understanding.

You mentioned having a vacation booked, and I'm curious about how you feel when you return to your routine after taking time off. It seems like the vacation provides temporary relief, but the depression returns once you're back at work. This cycle can be disheartening and leave you feeling stuck.

It's great that you're open to considering change. Sometimes, we need to take a step back and reassess our lives to see if there are any new opportunities or strategies that could help improve our situation. It's important to remember that change doesn't have to be drastic or overwhelming. Small steps can lead to significant progress.

Regarding your feelings of living in a paradox or dream, it's common for people to question the reality of their lives when they're going through a tough time. It might be helpful to explore these thoughts further and try to understand what triggers them. Journaling or talking to a trusted friend or family member about your experiences could provide some clarity.

Your mood swings, bad attitude, and bursts of anger are common symptoms of depression. It's important to remember that these feelings are valid and understandable given your circumstances. However, it's also important to take care of yourself and find healthy ways to cope with these emotions. [Question]
dutifully working a job that doesn t care about my humanity training people to replace me dutifully caring for a pet that make my mental health worse training them a i stress cry dutifully filling out tax for my dead parent emailing lawyer because my sibling won t fulfill their legal obligation dutifully attending counseling with my spouse actively listening to being told my want and need are wrong dutifully laying in bed quietly so a not do disturb anyone else staring at the ceiling through insomnia and intrusive thought understanding that i don t exist i am just a tool for everyone else this is my duty

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and trapped in a cycle of dutiful actions that don't bring you joy or fulfillment. It's important to remember that you have the power to take control of your life and prioritize your own well-being. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Reflect on your values: Take some time to think about what truly matters to you and what brings you a sense of purpose. This can help guide your decisions and actions moving forward.

2. Set boundaries: It's okay to say no when necessary. Learn to prioritize your own needs and set healthy boundaries with others. This can help reduce feelings of being overwhelmed and ensure that you have time for activities that bring you joy.

3. Engage in self-care: Make sure to take care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. This could include activities such as exercise, meditation, hobbies, or spending time with loved ones. Prioritizing self-care can help improve your overall well-being and reduce stress.

4. Seek support: Consider reaching out to trusted friends, family members, or a mental health professional for support. Sometimes talking to someone who cares about you can provide valuable perspective and guidance.

5. Explore new interests: Try exploring new hobbies or activities that you find interesting. This can help broaden your horizons and provide a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

6. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness exercises, such as deep breathing or meditation, can help calm your mind and reduce stress. Taking a few minutes each day to practice mindfulness can have a positive impact on your mental health.

7. Prioritize self-reflection: Take some time each day to reflect on your thoughts and feelings. Journaling or simply taking a few moments to pause and think can help you gain clarity and insight into your emotions.

8. Practice gratitude: Each day, try to identify at least three things you are grateful for. This can help shift your focus towards the positive aspects of your life and improve your overall mood.

9. Consider therapy: Speaking with a mental health professional can provide you with valuable guidance and support. They can help you explore your feelings, develop coping strategies, and work towards achieving a more balanced and fulfilling life.

10. Take small steps: Breaking down larger tasks into smaller, manageable steps can help reduce feelings of overwhelm. Celebrate each small accomplishment along the way to keep yourself motivated.

Remember, it's important to prioritize your own well-being and take care of yourself. You deserve to live a life that brings you joy and fulfillment.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm here to listen and support you, and I appreciate you reaching out for help. It takes a lot of courage to share your feelings, so I commend you for taking this step.

It sounds like you've been through a lot in your life, and it's understandable that you're feeling uncertain about what you want right now. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to question and reassess our desires and goals.

Regarding your friend who had suicidal thoughts, it's important to acknowledge that their influence can have a lasting impact on our lives. However, it's also crucial to recognize that you have the power to make choices that align with your values and goals. It might be helpful to explore the reasons behind your questioning of why we live and how it's affecting your motivation and goal setting. This could provide some insight into your current state of mind and help you gain clarity on what you truly want in life.

In terms of maintaining energy and having a positive outlook, it's essential to prioritize self-care. This includes getting enough sleep, eating well, exercising regularly, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Additionally, surrounding yourself with supportive and understanding people can make a significant difference. Building a strong support system can provide you with the encouragement and motivation you need to keep going.

It's also important to remember that everyone experiences ups and downs in their lives. It's normal to have periods of feeling low or unmotivated. However, if these feelings persist and start to interfere with your daily life, it may be helpful to seek professional support from a mental health expert. They can provide you with additional tools and strategies to cope with your current situation and help you regain your motivation and positive outlook.

Remember, you're not alone in this. There are people out there who care about you and want to support you. It might take some time, but with the right support and strategies, you can overcome these challenges and find a renewed sense of purpose and motivation in life.

i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of sadness and pain lately, and it's understandable that it's been difficult for you. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to start addressing these feelings.

Firstly, it might be helpful to reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and let them know what you've been going through. Sharing your emotions with someone who cares about you can provide a sense of relief and support.

Additionally, consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert. They can offer guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. Therapy can provide a safe space for you to explore your emotions and develop coping strategies.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to help manage your emotions. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or exercise, can help improve your mood. Taking care of your physical health by getting enough sleep, eating well, and avoiding excessive alcohol or drug use can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

It's also important to remember that healing takes time and it's okay to take things at your own pace. Be patient with yourself and try not to judge yourself too harshly for any setbacks or challenges you may encounter along the way.

Lastly, if you find yourself struggling with intense emotions or thoughts that feel overwhelming, it's crucial to reach out for immediate help. Contacting a helpline or crisis hotline can provide you with immediate support and guidance.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being. Reach out for support when you need it, and know that there are resources available to help you navigate through this difficult time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety and discomfort when certain topics or comments are made, even if they're not directly aimed at you. It's understandable that this can be really challenging and frustrating for you. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Recognize and challenge negative thoughts: When you have these anxiety attacks, try to identify the negative thoughts or assumptions that are fueling them. For example, if someone says something that you disagree with, try to remind yourself that it's just their opinion and doesn't necessarily reflect your own beliefs.

2. Practice self-compassion: It's important to be kind to yourself during these moments. Remember that everyone has their own preferences and opinions, and it's okay to disagree. Treat yourself with the same compassion and understanding that you would offer to a friend in a similar situation.

3. Communicate openly: If you find yourself in a conversation where someone makes a comment that triggers your anxiety, try to communicate your feelings openly and honestly. You can say something like, "I appreciate your opinion, but I'd rather not discuss that topic right now." By expressing your boundaries, you can help prevent future triggers and reduce the likelihood of an anxiety attack.

4. Seek support: Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide a listening ear and offer support. Sometimes just talking about your experiences and feelings can help alleviate some of the anxiety.

5. Practice relaxation techniques: When you feel an anxiety attack coming on, try deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation to help calm your body and mind. These techniques can help reduce the intensity of your physical symptoms and provide a sense of relief.

6. Challenge the need for perfection: It's important to remember that you don't have to be perfect in every situation. Allow yourself to make mistakes and learn from them. Remember that everyone has their own unique qualities and strengths, and it's okay to be imperfect.

7. Consider professional help: If your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health therapist. They can provide you with additional tools and strategies to manage your anxiety and help you develop coping mechanisms.

Remember, it takes time and practice to overcome anxiety, but with patience and self-compassion, you can work towards reducing its impact on your life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of anxiety and it's been really challenging for you. I can imagine how frustrating it must be to feel like nothing is helping. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another.

Given the recent worsening of your anxiety attacks, it might be helpful to consider reaching out to a healthcare professional who can provide you with further guidance and support. They can assess your symptoms more comprehensively and explore alternative treatment options if necessary.

In the meantime, there are some strategies you can try to help manage your anxiety. One technique that might be helpful is deep breathing exercises. When you feel an anxiety attack coming on, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce feelings of anxiety.

Another technique you could try is grounding yourself in the present moment. This involves focusing on your senses and bringing your attention to what's happening right now. You can do this by noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. It can also help reduce stress and improve sleep quality. Finding an activity that you enjoy and that fits into your routine can make it easier to stick with.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore relaxation techniques such as progressive muscle relaxation or mindfulness meditation. These practices can help calm your mind and body and promote a sense of relaxation.

Lastly, it's important to prioritize self-care. Make sure you're getting enough restful sleep, eating well-balanced meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Taking care of yourself can help improve your overall well-being and reduce anxiety.

Remember, these are just a few suggestions and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to find what works best for you and to be patient with yourself as you explore different strategies. If your anxiety continues to worsen or significantly impacts your daily life, it's important to reach out to a healthcare professional for further guidance and support.

 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of guilt and self-blame, which can be really challenging to cope with. It's important to remember that everyone experiences feelings of guilt from time to time, and it's a natural response to certain situations. However, when these feelings become overwhelming and start affecting your well-being, it's crucial to seek support.

One suggestion I have is to practice self-compassion. This means treating yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would treat a close friend. Remember that it's okay to make mistakes and that everyone has their limits. It's also important to recognize that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with the same feelings of guilt and self-blame.

Another suggestion is to establish boundaries. It's okay to say no when you're feeling overwhelmed or when you need some time for yourself. Communicate your needs to others and let them know that you're there for them, but that you also need time to recharge. Setting boundaries can help prevent you from feeling overwhelmed and can allow you to prioritize your own well-being.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can also be helpful. This might include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or practicing mindfulness and meditation. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can help reduce feelings of guilt and exhaustion.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with additional guidance and support. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your feelings of guilt and self-blame and develop strategies to cope with them more effectively. Remember, seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

[Question]
i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety and it's making it difficult for you to relax. It's understandable that the thought of sitting down and doing something calming, like reading or watching TV, can be overwhelming. Your mind is constantly racing with thoughts about what needs to be done and the pressure to relax.

One suggestion I have is to try breaking down your tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. Instead of thinking about sitting down to read for an hour, try setting aside just a few minutes at a time to read. You could start with just a few pages or even a few sentences. By starting small, you may find it easier to focus on the present moment and allow yourself to relax.

Another strategy that might help is creating a relaxing environment. You mentioned that you like to work out at the gym, so perhaps you could create a similar atmosphere at home. You could try using calming scents, such as essential oils, or playing soft music to help create a sense of calm. Additionally, you might find it helpful to engage in activities that you enjoy, even if they're not directly related to relaxation. For example, if you enjoy studying, you could make it a rewarding experience by studying in a comfortable environment and setting small achievable goals for yourself.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to prioritize self-care and relaxation. Sometimes, we put ourselves last on our to-do lists and forget that we need time to recharge. I encourage you to schedule regular relaxation time into your day, even if it's just for a few minutes. This way, you'll be more likely to actually engage in these activities and give yourself the rest and relaxation that you need.

Lastly, it might be helpful to explore the root causes of your anxiety. Are there any specific triggers or situations that tend to make your anxiety worse? Understanding what triggers your anxiety can help you develop strategies to manage it more effectively. It could be beneficial to keep a journal and track your thoughts and feelings throughout the day. This can help you identify patterns and gain insight into what might be contributing to your anxiety.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself. Relaxation takes practice and it's normal to feel anxious about it. I encourage you to try some of these strategies and see if they help you find a balance between relaxation and productivity. If you continue to struggle with anxiety and finding time to relax, it might be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
