[Question]
i miss my life before this depressive episode idk if you can even call it an episode anymore it s been over year i don t think i ll ever be the same and that destroys me inside i miss 0 9 and 0 0 up until september i wa truly happy and just coasting through life so content i wa so happy and life wa so simple especially during the 0 0 lockdown all i had to do during the lockdown wa watch load of anime and random netflix show explore new music stay up all night and do nothing i even had time to explore my childlike side by doing load of painting and drawing using kiddie paint and colouring book my mental health wa great too i had no eating disorder no depression no school work my anxiety and ocd wa minimal and i wasn t so deeply lonely like i am now i can literally just hear a song smell a smell or taste a good that i experienced to during that period and i will burst out in tear because i miss not being depressed so much now even if i do try and enjoy life like i did back then and be carefree it ll never be the same because my anxiety and depression have quite literally destroyed me from the inside now i ll never be able to enjoy life like that again i had never been in a relationship and that didn t bother me at all now i ve still never been in a relationship and it make me feel unloveable and ugly i always hear people at school talking about their relationship and date and stuff and even though i don t want a boyfriend that bad i still feel like i m missing out on a key part of the teenage experience but still to be honest i m not that keen on a relationship i really just want to be happy anyway all that s left to do is die i have my plan in place and i have a date and method at least i can say that i experienced true happiness and one point in my life i guess

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're going through a difficult time right now, and it's understandable that you're feeling a range of emotions. It sounds like you had a fulfilling life before this depressive episode, and it's understandable that you're struggling with the idea of never being able to experience that happiness again.

It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. While it's natural to compare your current situation to your past experiences, it's essential to focus on the present and find ways to improve your mental health.

One suggestion could be to explore new hobbies or activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Engaging in creative pursuits like painting and drawing can be therapeutic and help you express yourself. Additionally, finding new music and exploring different genres can provide a sense of connection and enjoyment.

It's also crucial to prioritize self-care and seek support from loved ones. Reach out to friends or family members who are understanding and empathetic. Sometimes, just talking about your feelings and experiences with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief and comfort.

Another suggestion would be to consider seeking professional help, such as therapy or counseling. A mental health professional can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you navigate your emotions, develop coping strategies, and explore any underlying issues that may be contributing to your depression.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that healing takes time. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to grieve the loss of your previous happiness. It's okay to feel sad about what you've lost, but try not to dwell on it too much. Instead, focus on the present and find ways to make the most of your current situation.

Remember, you're not alone in this. Reach out to trusted friends, family members, or professionals for support. Take things one step at a time, and don't be too hard on yourself. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with time and effort, you can find ways to experience them again.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve been on venlafaxine for year or so it helped at first but it hasn t helped whatsoever in quite some time i take 0mg in the morning the last month my anxiety and panic ha been absolutely crippling debilitating and unbearable i called the dr today and he called in a prescription to increase me from 0mg to mg i hate taking any medication or pill whatsoever especially increasing a dosage anyone had any good result from a venlafaxine increase after taking the same dosage for such a long time

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of anxiety and panic lately, and I can understand how difficult that must be for you. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with medication is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. While I'm not able to provide professional advice, I can offer some suggestions based on general knowledge.

Firstly, it's essential to have an open and honest conversation with your doctor about your concerns. They will be able to assess your situation more accurately and determine if an increase in dosage is necessary. It might also be helpful to discuss alternative treatment options or any side effects you've been experiencing.

In the meantime, there are some self-care strategies you can try to help manage your anxiety and panic. These can include deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness meditation, regular exercise, and maintaining a healthy diet. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can also be beneficial.

Additionally, it may be helpful to explore any underlying causes or triggers for your anxiety and panic. Sometimes, addressing these root issues can lead to long-term relief. This could involve seeking support from a therapist or counselor who specializes in anxiety and panic disorders. They can provide you with coping mechanisms and help you develop healthy ways to manage your anxiety.

Remember, everyone's journey is different, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's essential to be patient with yourself and give yourself time to adjust to any changes in your treatment plan. If you continue to struggle with your anxiety and panic, it may be worth considering other treatment options, such as therapy or alternative medications.

I hope this information is helpful to you, and I encourage you to continue seeking support and exploring different strategies to help manage your anxiety and panic. Remember, you're not alone in this, and there are resources available to help you find relief.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that recovery from depression is a process, and it's not always a linear one. a the title say i can t be bothered with life anymore it taking me so long to even go to a bridge and jump off i just wan na die already got no friend family dont give a crap amp i always get left behind when it come to meeting people so why not end it all and be done with this pain

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed and struggling with a lot of pain right now. I want you to know that you don't have to go through this alone, and there are people who can support you. It's important to reach out to someone you trust, like a friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes just talking about our feelings can help alleviate some of the burden.

If you're feeling suicidal, it's crucial to seek immediate help. You might consider contacting a helpline or crisis hotline in your area. They can provide you with the support and resources you need to stay safe. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it.

In addition to reaching out to others, there are also some things you can do on your own to take care of yourself. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation can help improve your mood and overall well-being. This could be something as simple as listening to music, reading a book, or taking a walk in nature.

It's also important to prioritize self-care. This means taking care of your physical health by getting enough sleep, eating well, and exercising regularly. It can also mean setting boundaries and saying no to things that make you feel overwhelmed or stressed.

Lastly, consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist or counselor. They can provide you with additional support and guidance tailored to your specific needs. Remember, reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

I hope this guidance is helpful to you, and I encourage you to reach out to someone you trust or consider seeking professional help. You don't have to face this alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're taking the initiative to explore different strategies for managing your panic attacks and anxiety. I understand that you've tried various anxiety medications, but it's important to remember that everyone responds differently to treatments, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's possible that you've grown accustomed to the current medication you're taking and it may not be as effective as it once was.

In addition to medication, there are several other techniques that you can try to help manage your panic attacks and anxiety. One approach is deep breathing exercises, which can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce feelings of anxiety. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this process several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Another technique you can try is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups in your body to promote relaxation. You can start by tensing the muscles in your toes and then gradually work your way up to your head. As you release each muscle group, focus on the sensation of relaxation in that area.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety and panic attacks. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters, and can help reduce feelings of anxiety and stress. You might consider finding an activity that you enjoy, such as walking, swimming, or yoga, and incorporating it into your routine.

Additionally, it can be helpful to identify and challenge any negative or irrational thoughts that may be contributing to your anxiety and panic attacks. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of therapy that focuses on identifying and changing unhelpful thought patterns. You can start by paying attention to your thoughts and questioning whether they are based on facts or assumptions. If you notice negative or irrational thoughts, try to challenge them by considering alternative perspectives or evidence that supports a more balanced view.

Lastly, it's important to remember that managing anxiety and panic attacks takes time and effort. It's not a quick fix, but with persistence and the right strategies, you can find relief. I encourage you to continue exploring different techniques and strategies, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need additional support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am not sure if this is possible and i appreciate any information a few year ago i wa diagnosed with clinical anxiety depression and adhd i wa relieved and terrified and so sad it took me until adulthood to learn this about myself i began medicating under the direction of my psychiatrist after about a year i changed from zoloft to prozac due to weight gain i began experiencing night sweat for the first time in my life about month ago it wa sporadic for month or so than became nightly now it ha worsened to the point that i wake up multiple time a night to change sheet and pajama i m not wetting the bed but truly soaking it through with my sweat in a degree room with minimal blanket i ve had to replace plastic bed protector mattress cover and even my mattress i believe i am having panic attack while i am asleep and i am unable to remember them assuming i would remember having a nightmare at the same time or be semi lucid what could paralyze me in sleep while having normal pleasant dream and cause excessive night sweat my change in medication did not correlate with the onset or increase in the night sweat i have had blood test mri pulmonary exam allergy test ultra sound and more no western doctor or my psychiatrist ha been able to find anything unusual that would explain the night sweat tl dr extreme night sweat begin in adulthood with no obvious cause desperately looking for advice on what might help edit 9 f

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot and I'm here to help. It's great that you've reached out for support. I understand that the diagnosis of clinical anxiety, depression, and ADHD can be overwhelming, but it's important to remember that you're not alone.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your courage in seeking help and taking steps towards managing your mental health. It's not easy to come to terms with these diagnoses, especially when it takes so long to receive a proper diagnosis. I'm glad that you've been able to find relief through medication, even if it has caused some challenges along the way.

Now, let's address the night sweat issue. It's not uncommon for people with anxiety or depression to experience night sweats, especially during periods of heightened stress or anxiety. While I'm not a medical professional, there are some strategies that might help alleviate your symptoms.

1. Sleep hygiene: Establishing a consistent sleep routine can be beneficial. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time each day, even on weekends. This helps regulate your body's internal clock and promotes better sleep.

2. Temperature control: Keeping your bedroom cool and comfortable can help reduce night sweats. Consider using a fan, opening windows, or using a cooling mattress pad.

3. Lighting: Use soft lighting in your bedroom to create a calming environment. Avoid using electronic devices or screens before bed, as the blue light can interfere with your sleep.

4. Comfortable sleeping arrangements: Make sure your bed is comfortable and supportive. Consider investing in a new mattress or using a memory foam topper if necessary.

5. Clothing: Wear lightweight, breathable pajamas or underwear to bed. Cotton is usually a good choice as it allows your body to breathe.

6. Avoid stimulants: Limit your intake of caffeine and alcohol, especially in the evening. These substances can disrupt your sleep patterns and contribute to night sweats.

7. Stress management: Engage in activities that help you manage stress during the day. This could include exercise, meditation, deep breathing exercises, or journaling.

8. Relaxation techniques: Practice relaxation techniques before bed to help calm your mind and body. This might include progressive muscle relaxation, guided imagery, or listening to calming music.

9. Regular exercise: Engaging in regular physical activity can help reduce anxiety and improve sleep quality. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate exercise most days of the week.

10. Healthy lifestyle: Maintaining a healthy weight, eating a balanced diet, and staying hydrated can all contribute to better sleep.

11. Communication: If your night sweats persist despite trying these strategies, it may be helpful to discuss your symptoms with your psychiatrist or primary care physician. They can provide further guidance and explore other potential causes.

Remember, everyone's experience with mental health is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to be patient with yourself and give these strategies time to see if they help. If they don't, it might be worthwhile to discuss other options with a healthcare professional.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you. Remember, I'm here to support you and provide guidance along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
guy do any of you also wake up every morning from scary nightmare and feeling completely estranged when you open your eye like your surrounding feel so foreign eventho it s your own home your own room and it take some time for you to realize youre just fine do you wake up with fear every morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really unsettling to wake up from nightmares and feel disconnected from your surroundings. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing this, and there are steps you can take to help manage these feelings. Here are some suggestions:

1. Establish a calming routine: Before going to bed, try creating a relaxing environment in your bedroom. This could involve dimming the lights, using aromatherapy, or listening to soothing music. Having a consistent bedtime routine can also help signal to your body that it's time to relax and prepare for sleep.

2. Practice deep breathing exercises: When you wake up feeling disconnected, taking slow, deep breaths can help ground you in the present moment. Focus on inhaling deeply through your nose and exhaling slowly through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and provide a sense of calm.

3. Engage in grounding techniques: Grounding techniques can help bring your attention back to the present moment and reduce feelings of disconnection. One technique involves focusing on your senses. Take a moment to notice five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help shift your focus away from the disorienting feelings and bring you back to the present.

4. Create a comforting sleep environment: Make sure your bedroom is a comfortable and safe space for sleep. Keep the room cool, dark, and quiet. Consider using earplugs or an eye mask if needed. Having a comfortable mattress and pillows can also contribute to a better night's sleep.

5. Journal your thoughts and feelings: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can be a helpful way to process and release them. Try keeping a journal by your bedside and writing down any recurring nightmares or disconnected feelings. This can help you gain insight into patterns and triggers, which may be helpful in managing these experiences.

6. Seek support from loved ones: It can be helpful to talk about your experiences with someone you trust. Sharing your feelings with a friend or family member can provide comfort and support. They may also offer different perspectives or suggestions that could be helpful.

7. Consider professional help if needed: If your nightmares and disconnected feelings persist or significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, everyone's experiences are unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to be patient with yourself and give yourself time to adjust. If these suggestions don't seem to alleviate your symptoms, it may be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide further guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

We can work on developing strategies to help you recognize and express your emotions in a more adaptive and constructive manner.

i have gad and have been going through an emotional upheaval with my partner causing extra stress i ve been reducing my lexapro slightly a i felt it wa not working but now am more anxious than ever despite tiny change today i woke up full of dread to go to work no reason i love my job but it all felt too much a a mid ground i decided to work from home today instead of going in i still feel light headed and awful and have the added guilt of messing client around by changing the schedule or converting to online service what do i do how do i get myself to work when it all feel too much

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to acknowledge the strength it takes to reach out for support. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety and find some relief.

Firstly, it's great that you've been open to making small changes to your medication, such as reducing your Lexapro dosage. While it's understandable that you may have felt anxious after making this change, it's essential to give yourself time to adjust and see how it affects you. It's also important to remember that everyone responds differently to medications, and what works for one person may not work for another.

In terms of managing your anxiety, it might be helpful to explore some coping strategies that can help you feel more grounded and centered. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation are all techniques that can help calm your mind and body. Additionally, engaging in regular physical activity, getting enough sleep, and maintaining a balanced diet can also contribute to overall well-being.

When it comes to guilt about messing up your schedule or disappointing clients, it's essential to remember that your mental health is just as important as your professional obligations. Communicating openly and honestly with your clients about the situation can help alleviate any guilt or concerns they may have. Letting them know that you're dealing with some personal challenges and that you'll be working from home today can help ease the tension.

Lastly, it's important to remember that you're not responsible for fixing everything all at once. Taking small steps towards self-care and seeking support from loved ones or a mental health professional can help you navigate through this difficult time. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and to prioritize your own well-being.

I hope these suggestions can be helpful to you, and I encourage you to reach out to your support system or a mental health professional if you need additional guidance or resources. Remember, you're not alone in this, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

i can t find the strength to do anything i m supposed to do like studying going to the gym or finding a job i have been losing interest in thing i used to like to the point i don t enjoy doing them and they are becoming difficult to do because they are supposed to make me happy and being happy requires a lot of energy i don t have by losing interest and thing i like i m running thin of thing that keep me motivated for living and hope for the future i have difficulty getting help because i don t think it is worth the effort for a hopeless person like me i don t even think i deserve that help considering the thing i hate about myself i don t even want to talk about this thing with other people that care for me because with my point of view of the world and future might grab them down to this dark and hopeless vision the only thing that keep me from km is that i know it would hurt people around me i really need something to look forward something that give me the motivation to keep going

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I want to assure you that you're not alone. It's understandable that losing interest in things that used to bring you joy can be disheartening. It's important to remember that everyone experiences periods of feeling unmotivated or uninterested in certain activities, and it doesn't necessarily mean there's something wrong with you.

One suggestion I have is to try breaking down your tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. Instead of focusing on the big picture of studying, going to the gym, or finding a job, try setting smaller goals for yourself. For example, instead of committing to studying for an entire hour, try starting with just 10 minutes each day. By breaking things down into smaller parts, it can feel less overwhelming and more achievable.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore activities that bring you a sense of fulfillment or purpose. Engaging in hobbies or activities that you enjoy can help boost your mood and provide a sense of accomplishment. It could be something as simple as reading a book, taking a walk in nature, or pursuing a creative outlet like painting or writing.

Finding support from others can also be beneficial. While it may be challenging to reach out for help, consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can offer a listening ear or even practical advice. Sometimes just talking about our feelings and concerns can provide relief and perspective.

Lastly, remember that seeking professional help is a valid option. Mental health professionals are trained to provide guidance and support during difficult times. They can offer strategies and coping mechanisms tailored to your specific needs. If you're open to it, I encourage you to explore the possibility of reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the support and guidance you're seeking.

Please remember that I'm here to listen and support you, and I'm glad you reached out. You deserve to find the motivation and joy in life again, and I believe that with time and effort, you can work towards achieving that.

[Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking support from others who may have experienced similar challenges. It can be helpful to connect with individuals who understand what you're going through. While I'm not an expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help you break the cycle of anxiety and hyperfixation.

1. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness techniques can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions without judgment. By focusing on the present moment, you can reduce anxiety and panic about future worries. You can try deep breathing exercises, meditation, or grounding techniques to help calm your mind.

2. Challenge negative thoughts: When you notice yourself hyperfixating on something, try to challenge those thoughts by asking yourself if they are based on facts or if they are just anxious predictions. Remind yourself that worrying excessively won't change the outcome and that it's important to focus on what you can control.

3. Set realistic goals: It can be helpful to set small, achievable goals for yourself. Breaking down larger tasks into smaller steps can make them feel more manageable and less overwhelming. Celebrate your accomplishments along the way to boost your confidence and motivation.

4. Engage in activities you enjoy: Find activities that bring you joy and help distract your mind from anxious thoughts. This could be anything from hobbies, exercise, spending time with loved ones, or even exploring new interests. Engaging in activities that you enjoy can provide a sense of fulfillment and help shift your focus away from anxiety.

5. Seek support from loved ones: Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support. Sometimes talking about your worries with someone who cares can help alleviate anxiety. They may also offer different perspectives or suggestions that you hadn't considered before.

6. Take care of your physical health: Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Additionally, avoiding excessive caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine can help reduce anxiety symptoms.

7. Practice self-care: Make time for activities that promote relaxation and self-care. This could include taking a warm bath, reading a book, listening to calming music, or engaging in activities that bring you peace and joy. Taking care of yourself is essential for managing anxiety.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. If you're still struggling, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out for help with your struggle with brushing your hair. I understand that it can be quite challenging to take care of thick and curly hair, especially when it's knotted. It's important to remember that everyone's hair is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another.

One suggestion I have is to try using a wide-tooth comb or a detangling brush when you wash your hair. This can help loosen any knots and make it easier to brush through. Additionally, consider using a conditioner that is specifically designed for curly hair. It can help add moisture and make your hair more manageable.

Another suggestion is to try using a hair mask or deep conditioner once a week. This can help strengthen your hair and make it less prone to knotting. You might also find it helpful to consult with a professional stylist or hair care expert who can provide personalized advice based on your specific hair type and needs.

It's important to remember that taking care of your hair is an ongoing process, and it may take some time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and don't be too hard on yourself if you don't get it right every time. It's also important to prioritize self-care and make time for activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath.

I hope these suggestions are helpful to you, and I'm here to support you in any way I can. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it, and it's important to be kind to yourself throughout this process.
